bibl.title: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William Crawford Gorgas, November 30, 1918

div1.p: Carter writes that it would make little sense for him to go to Guatemala for yellow fever work now.

div1.head: Letter from [Henry Rose Carter] to William Crawford Gorgas, November 30, 1918
div1.opener:
Miscl
Y. F.
/LC
November 30, 1918.
Dear Gorgas:
div1.p: I want to explain the embroglio of this morning.

I wrote you Sunday evening. The next morning Blue asked me
what I thought of going to Guatemala to look into the yellow fever
situation--said that you and Heiser were going. I told him I was
too tired to think just then, but was well and could do whatever
was advisable--I had just gotten up from Sabine, Texas.

Last evening, about 8.30, I got a telegram to expect orders
for Guatemala: said you would said December 5th., and to go over to
the Bureau for conference and passport. I put things in train to
leave and went to the Bureau. Found it was intended for me to go
with your party for the purpose of getting data on the yellow fever
situation in Central America to determine what measures the Service
should take in maritime quarantine. Naturally, this would be
very much better determined next March or April than now--yellow
fever is not a threat to the U. S. during the winter--no Stegomyia
being active in our ports--and it would be a very wise man who
could now predict at all accurately what will be the condition of
any Central American port next summer. Especially is this true
since, as I understand, measures to eradicate the disease are--and
will be taken. I persuaded Dr. Blue of this and then called you
up.

Frankly, I would have liked very well to have taken a “paseo”
with you, but that is all it would have been and there is a lot
of malaria work I want to get organized on a peace basis and I don't
feel I have any right to loaf on it. If I had, I have been at home
so little since January 5th. that I had rather spend any leisure
I will have with my family. I will be extremely glad to go with
you when there is any service I can render.

Found both of your letters on my return. I felt pretty cer-
tain thay you could doonothing about Henry. He just played in
bad luck. There is no reason why he should feel so badly about it,
but he is no very philosophic.
